openalea.celltissue.config module¶

Download the source file ../../src/celltissue/config.py.

This module defines a Config object to store informations in a nice way

class Config(name, items=[], info='')¶

Bases: object

Simple class to manage config files

Allow to access all properties defined into a python file using the dot operator.

Constructor

Parameters:

  • name (str) - name of this config

  • items (list of ConfigItem) -

    items stored in this configuration

  • info (str) - description of this

    configuration
add_item(item, section=None)¶

Add a new item to this configuration

Parameters:

  • item (ConfigItem) - item to add

  • section (int) - index of section in which

    to add the item. Default is None, the item is stored in the root of this configuration
add_section(section)¶

Add a new section

Section help to group items into logical entities.

Parameters:
  • section (Section) - the

    section to add
Return:

index of the section
Returns type:

int

class ConfigFormat(context, config=None)¶

Bases: object

Simple class to help creating configuration files

Constructor

Parameters:

  • context (dict) - local python env

  • config (Config) - configuration

    in which to store elements. Default is None, config will be created.
add(name, unit='', info='')¶

Add a new item in the current section

Create the item using the provided infos and set the value of this item according to the value of the element with name name in the context provided in the constructor.

Parameters:
  • name (str) - name of the item
  • unit (str) - unit description
  • info (str) - description of the item

See also

Config.add_item()

add_item(item)¶

Add an item to the current section

Parameters:
  • item (ConfigItem) - item to add

See also

Config.add_item()

add_section(title, info='')¶

Add a section to the configuration

The newly created section will become the current section in which further items will be added.

Parameters:

  • title (str) - name of the section

  • info ((str) - description of the

    section

See also

Config.add_section()

config()¶

Returns type:Config
class ConfigItem(name, value, unit='', info='')¶

Bases: object

Associate a value with a unit

Constructor

Parameters:

  • name (str) - name of this item

  • value (any) - actual value

  • unit (str) - string description

    of the unit (e.g. m, m.s-1,...)

  • info (str) - description of this

    item

openalea.celltissue.serial module¶

Download the source file ../../src/celltissue/serial.py.

This module defines functions to serialize a tissue

class TissueFile(filename, mode='r')¶

Bases: object

Object used to serialize a tissue

Constructor

Create a tissue file that will be stored in a file called filename.

Parameters:
  • filename (str) - name of the file in

    which to store or read informations

  • mode (str) - either ‘r’ to read or

    ‘w’ to write.

Note

Do not create this object directly, use topen() instead.

chmod(filename, mod=420)¶

Change file permissions

Parameters:

  • filename (str) - name of the file whose permissions have to be modified

  • mod (int) - numerical description

    of the permission (linux type)
close()¶
Write everything inside the file and close it.
configs()¶

Iterator on the name of all configurations stored in this archive.

Returns type:iter of str
external_files()¶

Iterator on the name of all external files stored in this archive.

External file means that the file is:
  • not a tissue,
  • not a property,
  • not a config file.
Returns type:iter of str
filenames()¶

Name of all files currently in the archive

Iterator on all name of files actually stored in this tissuefile object.

properties()¶

Iterator on the name of all properties stored in this archive.

Returns type:iter of str

    • else read property

tissue or property, description

set_compression(filename, comp=8)¶

Set the type of compression of a file in the archive

Default is ZIP_DEFLATED. Use this function if you need to change it.

set_time(filename, datetime=None)¶

Change the time of a stored file

Parameters:
  • filename (str) - name of the file

    whose date has to be modified

  • datetime (int,int,int,int,int,int) - new associated time

    in the form (year,month,day,hour,min,sec). Default is None, the function will then use the actual localtime.
write(obj, name=None, description='')¶

Magic function to store either a tissue or a property in the archive

Parameters:
  • obj (Tissue or dict) - object

    to store

  • name (str) - name to use to store the object

    if None, assume obj is a tissue else assume obj is a property

  • description (str) - textual description

    of the object

See also

- TissueFile.write_tissue() - TissueFile.write_property()

Parameters:
  • config (:class:Config) - configuration

    to store

  • config_name (str) - name to use to retrieve

    the configuration later

  • filename (str) - name of the file to use

    to later retrieve this info

  • description (str) - textual description

    of the data

    file in which to store data

    description of the data

Store a property in the archive

  • property_name (str) - name of the file to use

    to later retrieve this info

  • description (str) - textual description

    of the property
write_tissue(tissue)¶

Store a tissue in the archive

Only one tissue can be stored, so there is no need to provide a name to later retrieve the tissue.

Parameters:
  • tissue (Tissue) - tissue to store
topen(filename, mode='r')¶

Open a tissue file

Store or read informations in a file depending on the mode.

Parameters:

  • filename (str) - name of the file

  • mode (str) - either ‘r’ to read or

    ‘w’ to store informations
Returns type:

TissueFile

Note

Rather use this instead of the constructor of TissueFile

This module defines the main Tissue object

class Tissue(idgenerator='max')¶

Bases: object

Base class for all tissues

A tissue is a collection of elements and a set of links between these elements.

Examples:
>>> t = Tissue()
>>> CELL = t.add_type("cell")
>>> WALL = t.add_type("wall")
>>> gid = t.add_relation("graph",(CELL,WALL) )

Constructor

Parameters:
  • idgenerator (str) - specify the type of

    generator to use to later add new elements in the tissue:

    • ‘set’ use a set of empty ids
    • ‘list’ use a list of empty ids
    • ‘max’ always increase the ids

See also

openalea.container.IdDict to better understand idgenerator

add_element(type_id, elm_id=None, safe=True)¶

Add a new element of the given type in the tissue

Parameters:

  • type_id (type_id) - type of element to add

  • elm_id (elm_id) - id to use to store the

    element. If None (default), the function will create a new id

  • safe (bool) - if False, allow to overwrite

    an existing element else raise an InvalidElement if the provided elm_id already exists.
Return:

id used to store the element
Returns type:

elm_id

Note

type_id is of the same type than returned by Tissue.add_type()

add_relation(relation_type='graph', involved_types=[], relation_id=None)¶

Add a relation between different type of elements

Parameters:
  • relation_type (str) - a textual description
    of the relation:
    • ‘graph’ for a directed graph
    • ‘mesh’ for a topomesh
    • ‘relation’ for a bipartite graph
  • involved_types (list of type_id) - list the type

    of elements that will be involved in the relation. If the list contains None, a dummy type will be created to be used in this relation.

  • relation_id (relation_id) - provide an id to use

    to store the relation. If None (default), an id will be created by the function.
Return:

id used to store the relation
Returns type:

relation_id
Examples:
>>> t = Tissue()
>>> CELL = t.add_type("cell")
>>> WALL = t.add_type("wall")
>>> gid = t.add_relation("graph",(CELL,WALL) )

>>> t = Tissue()
>>> CELL = t.add_type("cell")
>>> gid = t.add_relation("graph",(CELL,None) )
add_type(name='elm', type_id=None)¶

Add a new type of elements in the tissue

Parameters:
  • name (str) - provide a textual name

    for this type (default is “elm”)

  • type_id (type_id) - use this id to store

    the new type. If None (default), the function will create a new id.
Return:

id used to store the new type
Returns type:

type_id
clear()¶
Clear all elements and relations in the tissue
elements(type_id=None)¶

Iterator on all elements of tissue with a given type.

if type_id is None, iterate on all elements whatever their type.

Parameters:
  • type_id (type_id) - type of elements

    to iterate on
Returns type:

iter of elm_id

Note

type_id is of the same type than returned by Tissue.add_type()

nb_elements(type_id=None)¶

Number of elements of the given type

Total number of elements in the tissue if type_id is None.

Parameters:
  • type_id (type_id) - type of elements

    to take into account
Returns type:

int

Note

type_id is of the same type than returned by Tissue.add_type()

nb_relations(type_id=None)¶

Number of relation involving the given type

if type_id is None, return the total number of relations maintained by the tissue.

Parameters:
  • type_id (type_id) - type of elements

    that must be involved in the relation
Returns type:

int

Note

type_id is of the same type than returned by Tissue.add_type()

relation(relation_id)¶

Retrieve a relation maintained by this tissue

Parameters:
  • relation_id (relation_id) - id of

    the relation you want to retrieve a reference on.
Returns type:

Relation

Note

relation_id is of the same type than returned by Tissue.add_relation()

relations(type_id=None)¶

Iterate on all relations involving the given type

if type_id is None, iterate on all relations maintained by the tissue.

Parameters:
  • type_id (type_id) - type of elements

    that must be involved in the relation
Returns type:

iter of relation_id

Note

  • type_id is of the same type than returned by Tissue.add_type()
  • relation_id is of the same type than returned by Tissue.add_relation()
remove_element(elm_id)¶

Remove the given element and all links in all relations that points to this element

Parameters:
  • elm_id (elm_id) - id of element to remove

Note

elm_id is of the same type than returned by Tissue.add_element()
